citations.narrative:
The facility is not maintaining an adequate pest control program in the animal room. An excessive amount of rodent feces
were observed on the floor near the guinea pig enclosure. Storage bins and unused cages containing old bedding are
stored in the corner behind cubicle walls. There were several feet of rodent feces on the floor in the storage corner next to
the guinea pig enclosure. On the other side of the room, several rodent feces pellets were present on an unopen bag of
guinea pig food.
Lack of an adequate pest control program can negatively impact the health and well-being of the animals as it can foster
the contamination of feed and transmission of diseases. The facility must ensure that a safe and effective program for the
control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests is established and maintained.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “B” license. A full inspection was not conducted due to circumstances that
arose during the inspection. This report contains all noncompliances identified up to the point the inspection was stopped.
No exit interview was conducted.
The licensee must demonstrate full compliance with the Act, regulations, and standards within 2 more inspections or by
March 20, 2026, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your
inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until March 20, 2026.
n

narrative:
3.131(d)  Repeat
   
Sanitation. 
The facility is not maintaining an adequate pest control program in the animal room. An excessive amount of rodent feces 
were observed on the floor near the guinea pig enclosure. Storage bins and unused cages containing old bedding are 
stored in the corner behind cubicle walls. There were several feet of rodent feces on the floor in the storage corner next to 
the guinea pig enclosure. On the other side of the room, several rodent feces pellets were present on an unopen bag of 
guinea pig food.  
 
Lack of an adequate pest control program can negatively impact the health and well-being of the animals as it can foster 
the contamination of feed and transmission of diseases. The facility must ensure that a safe and effective program for the 
control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests is established and maintained. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “B” license. A full inspection was not conducted due to circumstances that 
arose during the inspection. This report contains all noncompliances identified up to the point the inspection was stopped. 
No exit interview was conducted.  
 
The licensee must demonstrate full compliance with the Act, regulations, and standards within 2 more inspections or by 
March 20, 2026, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your 
inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until March 20, 2026.
